docs.lead_paragraph: STEVEN N. Blair, one of the nation's leading experts on the health benefits of exercise, is short and fat. Those are his words. The president and chief executive officer of the Cooper Institute, a nonprofit organization in Dallas dedicated to research on the relationship between living habits and health, Dr. Blair, 65, is 5-feet-5 and weighs 195 pounds. He's also a dedicated runner who habitually takes off for an hourlong jog. ''I'm a short, fat guy who runs every day,'' Dr. Blair said in a recent phone interview. ''I've run tens of thousands of miles over the past 40 years, and in that time I've gained 30 pounds.''
docs.snippet: Exercise may not help in losing as much weight as some people would like, but it's still beneficial for preventing disease.

headline.main: Some Extra Heft May Be Helpful, New Study Says

docs.abstract: Researchers at National Cancer Institute and Centers for Disease Control and Prevention find that people who are overweight but not obese have lower risk of death than those of normal weight and that being very thin causes slight increase in risk of death, even if thinness is longstanding and not related to disease; say increased risk of death from obesity is for most part in the extremely obese, group constituting only 8 percent of Americans; findings are unexpected and are met with full gamut of responses from experts; some see study as reality check on what they consider nation's near-hysteria over fat; others voice skepticism; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: People who are overweight but not obese have a lower risk of death than those of normal weight, federal researchers are reporting today. The researchers -- statisticians and epidemiologists from the National Cancer Institute and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention -- also found that increased risk of death from obesity was seen for the most part in the extremely obese, a group constituting only 8 percent of Americans.
docs.snippet: People who are overweight but not obese have a lower risk of death than those of normal weight, federal researchers said.

headline.main: As America Gets Bigger, The World Does, Too

docs.lead_paragraph: It's no secret that Americans are overweight. But obesity is a growing problem worldwide, even in countries whose populations have in the past been enviably lean, as new research reports make clear. In China, for example, about 18 million adults are obese and another 137 million are overweight, according to a study of 16,000 people published last week in The Lancet. Another report, in The New England Journal of Medicine, noted that in developing countries, ''as many as 60 percent of households with an underweight family member also have an overweight one.''
docs.snippet: Obesity is a growing problem worldwide, even in countries whose populations have in the past been enviably lean.

headline.main: Feeding the Hunger For the Next Diet Book

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Jorge Cruise, a suntanned fitness guru from San Diego, dropped in at the Barnes & Noble corporate headquarters in Manhattan the week his new book, ''The 3-Hour Diet,'' was due to arrive in stores, a number of the company's merchandising and marketing executives were already trying out the diet, happily digging into a lunch of fish, salami, green salad, couscous and a chocolate dessert. Convincing Americans that a diet that allows carbohydrates, fat and sugar might actually work is no easy task, but Mr. Cruise addressed the executives, who had gathered to discuss how to promote his book, with the exuberance of a late-night television pitchman.
docs.snippet: Is there a formula for an instant best seller? In the lucrative diet book industry, the recipe is nearly down to a science.
